metadata.title: Inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) regulatory region variation in 4 non-human primates 5 6 7

abstract.text: Please cite this article in press as: Roodgar, M., et al. Inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) regulatory region variation in non-human primates. Infect. Genet. Evol. (2015), http://dx.(Chlorocebus sabaeus), pig-tailed macaques (Macaca nemestrina), 81 cynomolgus macaques (Macaca fascicularis), Indian rhesus 82 macaques (M. mulatta), and Chinese rhesus macaques (M. mulatta).

Variation in regulation of iNOS expression may play a role in the var-84 iable susceptibility of these species to several infectious diseases 85 (Roodgar et al., 2013; Lyashchenko et al., 2007; McAuliffe et al., 86 2004). We investigated whether or not there is evidence for inter-87 species differences in the regulatory regions of iNOS that might 88 account for such variability in disease susceptibility. Since NOS2A 89 plays a key role in immunity against intracellular pathogens 90 (Wienerroither et al., 2014; Obermajer et al., 2013) relevant to 91 human health, information on DNA sequence variation in the regu-92 latory region of NOS2A in species of NHP that are more closely 93 related to humans than the mouse should provide better informa-94 tion about the relationship between variation in NOS2A gene expres-95 sion and human-like immune responses to intracellular pathogens 96 (Lyashchenko et al., 2007; McAuliffe et al., 2004). 97 We sequenced two candidate regulatory regions of the NOS2A 98 gene in several animals in each of five species or subspecies of 99 NHP that exhibit differing levels of susceptibility to infectious 100 respiratory diseases, especially tuberculosis. The basic primer 101 sequences for the candidate iNOS promoter regions were identified 102 using the human genome Chip-seq data available at the University 103 of California, Santa Cruz (UCSC) Genome Browser. We then used an 104 Applied Biosystems 3130XL genetic analyzer to produce DNA 105 sequence data for each sample. Sequences were aligned using 106 Kalign2 (Lassmann et al., 2009; Lassmann and Sonnhammer, 107 2006; Lassmann and Sonnhammer, 2005), and variation in the can-108 didate promoter regions was analyzed using the adegenet package 109 in the R programming environment (R Core Team, 2014). The effect 110 of cross-species genetic conservation and variation on transcrip-111 tion factor and regulatory element bindings sites was then 112 evaluated using the MatInspector software (Quandt et al., 1995; 113 Cartharius et al., 2005). 114 2. Results 115 2.1. Multiple sequence alignment and promoter localization 116 We localized the iNOS coding region and the candidate pro-117 moter/regulatory regions on the rhesus macaque and human refer-118 ence sequences using the NCBI genome browser. Fig. 1 plots the 119 location of the R2 region on the human reference sequence. 120 Multiple sequence alignment of R1 and R2 across species was 121 conducted using Kalign2 (Lassmann et al., 2009; Lassmann and 122 Sonnhammer, 2006; Lassmann and Sonnhammer, 2005). The 123 performance of the alignment was evaluated using Mumsa 124 (Lassmann and Sonnhammer, 2006) and visual inspection. The 125 Jalview program (Clamp et al., 2004; Waterhouse et al., 2009) 126 was used to visualize and trim the alignments and construct spe-127 cies-specific consensus sequences. In Fig. 2, we plot the animal-128 specific nucleotide sequences and species-specific consensus 129 sequences used in this analysis. 130 2.2. Promoter variation and interspecies clustering 131 To investigate whether or not variation in R1 and R2 followed 132 the pattern expected from the phylogenetic relationships among 133 these NHP species and subspecies, we used the R packages ape 134 and adegent to extract the SNPs from the aligned and trimmed 135 DNA sequences. We then used discriminant analysis of principal 136 components (DAPC) (Jombart et al., 2010) to investigate the 137 cross-species partitioning of genetic variation. 138

body_text.text: a b s t r a c t 30 Inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) is an enzyme that plays a key role in intracellular immune response 31 against respiratory infections. Since various species of nonhuman primates exhibit different levels of sus-32 ceptibility to infectious respiratory diseases, and since variation in regulatory regions of genes is thought 33 to play a key role in expression levels of genes, two candidate regulatory regions of iNOS were mapped, 34 sequenced, and compared across five species of nonhuman primates: African green monkeys (Chlorocebus 35 sabaeus), pig-tailed macaques (Macaca nemestrina), cynomolgus macaques (Macaca fascicularis), Indian 36 rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta), and Chinese rhesus macaques (M. mulatta). In addition, we conducted 37 an in silico analysis of the transcription factor binding sites associated with genetic variation in these two 38 candidate regulatory regions across species. We found that only one of the two candidate regions showed 39 strong evidence of involvement in iNOS regulation. Specifically, we found evidence of 13 conserved bind- (Chan et al., 1992; 55 MacMicking et al., 1997) . Genetic changes in the regulatory and/ 56 or coding regions of NOS2A, the gene encoding iNOS, might play 57 an important role in modulating expression levels of iNOS and, con-58 sequently, cause variation in immune response against intracellu-59 lar pathogens (Nanashima et al., 2012) . Several studies indicate 60 that genetic changes in the regulatory and/or coding region of 61 NOS2A are associated with susceptibility to various diseases 62 (Nanashima et al., 2012; Park et al., 2014; Lim et al., 2013; 63 AlFadhli et al., 2013; Fabisiewicz et al., 2013; Karasneh et al., 64 2011; Wang et al., 2013; Rafiei et al., 2012; Zhang et al., 2011; 65 Planche et al., 2010; Levesque et al., 2010) . It has been shown, 66 for example, that mutations in the promoter region of NOS2A cor-67 relate with susceptibility to malaria (Levesque et al., 2010) and 68 that iNOS expression levels are strongly driven by exposure to 69 Mycobacterium tuberculosis vaccination (Roodgar et al., 2013) . In 70 addition, recent epigenetic studies of the promoter and enhancers 71 of NOS2A in humans demonstrate the effect of changes in NOS2A 72 regulatory regions on iNOS expression (Gross et al., 2014) and 73 the pathogenesis of infectious diseases (de Andrés et al., 2013; 74 Angrisano et al., 2012; Jia et al., 2011; Hobbs et al., 2002) . 75 In this study, we investigated the patterning and functional sig- the first two principal components of variation. Fig. 3 To understand the possible phenotypic consequence of genetic 161 variation in the R1 and R2 regions and identify whether or not each 162 region is likely to be involved in regulation of iNOS transcription, 163 we conducted an in silico analysis of regulatory element (RE) and 164 transcription factor (TF) binding to the DNA sequences in R1 and 165 R2 using MatInspector (Quandt et al., 1995; Cartharius et al., 166 2005 AP-1, C/EBPB, CREB, GATA-1, GATA-3, NF-AT, NF-AT5, NF-jB, KLF4,

Oct-1, PEA3, SMAD3, and TCF11, 13 genes that have been previously 183 associated with iNOS regulation (Pautz et al., 2010; Liao et al., 184 2011), were conserved. In contrast, only 2 binding sites previously 185 associated with iNOS regulation were conserved in R1 (PPAR-c and 186 USF-1) (Pautz et al., 2010 Table 3 . The blue crosses indicate the true group assignment, and the cell color indicates increasing group assignment probability (based on SNP data) as the scale shifts from yellow to red. We note three distinct genetic clusters in R1 (African green monkey, rhesus macaque, and cynomolgus/pig-tailed macaques), and four distinct genetic clusters in R2 (African green monkey, Indian rhesus macaque, Chinese rhesus macaque, and cynomolgus/pig-tailed macaques). (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Table 3 for the codebook linking each RE/TF binding site to each data point in the plot) plotted in barycentric space using a tertiary plot to represent the relative strength of association across categories. Data points in the center cluster of the plotting space are not indicative of interspecies differences in RE/TF binding sites; data points located near the boundary of the triangle are indicative of interspecies differences in RE/TF binding. Only a small fraction of the RE/TF binding sites identified in our analysis are indicative of interspecies differences.

Additionally, we found evidence of interspecies variation in binding 42 sites for several regulatory elements linked to iNOS (GATA-3, GATA-4, KLF6, SRF, STAT-1, STAT-3, OLF-1 and 43 HIF-1) across species, especially in African green monkeys relative to other species. Given the key role of 44 iNOS in respiratory immune response, the findings of this study might help guide the direction of future 45 studies aimed to uncover the molecular mechanisms underlying the increased susceptibility of African 46 green monkeys to several viral and bacterial respiratory infections. oxide synthase (iNOS) is an enzyme that plays a 53 key role in immune response against pathogens through the pro-54 duction of peroxinitrite in macrophages

FIGREF14.text: Discriminant analysis of principal components in regions R1 (Frame 3a) and R2 (Frame 3b). The first principal component (horizontal axis) separates African green monkeys from the other species in both R1 and R2. The second principal component (vertical axis) separates Rhesus macaques from cynomolgus and pig-tailed macaques. GATA-3, NF-AT, NF-AT5, NF-jB, KLF4, Oct-1, PEA3, SMAD3, and 248 TCF11) in R2 across species. In addition to the results of in silico 249 analyses presented here (Pautz et al., 2010; Liao et al., 2011; 250 Kleinert et al., 2004), many of these transcription factors have been 251 shown to play a key role in the regulation of iNOS expression in 252 laboratory studies. In contrast, we identified only two conserved 253 binding sites previously linked to iNOS regulation (PPAR-c and 254 USF-1) in R1 (Pautz et al., 2010). These results provide evidence 255that R2 is a more appropriate candidate region for iNOS regulation 256 in these species of NHPs than R1.257In the list of conserved RE/TF binding sites across these species 258 of NHP, NF-jB is the most well-studied transcription factor known 259 an important role in regulation of iNOS expression(Uffort et al.,   260   2009;Chan et al., 2001;Jaramillo et al., 2003; Oussaief et al.,   261   2011;Kelleher et al., 2007;Feng et al., 2002). Previous studies have 262 shown that NF-jB modulates iNOS expression during various viral,263    bacterial, and parasitic infections(Oussaief et al., 2011; Chan et al.,   264   2001;Jaramillo et al., 2003). It has also been shown that interfer-265 ence in the NF-jB-dependent regulation of iNOS expression is part 266 of the pathogenic mechanism for Helicobacter pylori(Kim et al.,   267    2003); a similar mechanism may be involved in the pathogenesis 268 of other infectious diseases (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis).

FIGREF15.text: Non-conserved RE/TF binding sites 270 While searching for interspecies differences in TF binding sites 271 in R1 and R2, we found evidence of a decreased association of bind-272 ing sites for HOXB8; GATA-4, DLX3; CDX1; HOXA9; HOXB6; IRF4; 273 ZNF384; TEF; MSX3; MEOX1, and HSF2 with African green monkeys 274 relative to other species in R1, as well as a decreased association of 275 binding sites for ELF-1, GLS3; HOXB9; SMARCA2; OLF-1, and TIEG 276 with African green monkeys relative to other species in R2. 277 Additionally, we found an increased association of binding sites 278 for GATA-3, MEIS1; PU:1=SPI À 1, and EBF1 in R1, and an increased 279 association of binding sites for GCM1; GLIS2; KLF6; MAZ; MTBF; 280 NM23; PAX6; RTR; SRF; STAT-1, STAT-3, ZIC2, and ZNF219 in R2, with 281 African green monkeys relative to other species. 282 Some of the SNPs we have identified might be responsible for 283 interspecies differences in iNOS regulation and expression, as well 284 as susceptibility to diseases linked to iNOS expression levels, such 285 as tuberculosis. While there is no clear biological link between 286 many of the genes cited above and iNOS production, several of 287 these genes (e.g. GATA-3, GATA-4, KLF6; SRF; STAT-1, STAT-3, OLF-288 1 and HIF-1) have been linked to iNOS regulation in laboratory 289 studies (Pautz et al., 2010).

FIGREF16.text: significant role of STAT proteins in inducing IFN-293 dependent expression of MHC II in macrophages(Zhao et al.,   294    2007), interspecies variation in STAT binding sites might contribute295    to variation in innate immune response across these species. STAT-296 1, specifically, is known to be an important transcription factor for 297 regulating iNOS expression(Ganster et al., 2001; Ohmori and   298   Hamilton, 2001). Since several studies indicate a significant role 299 for STAT-1 in iNOS activation and expression(Samardzic et al.,    300 2001), variation in STAT-1 binding sites across these species might 301 contribute to variable susceptibility to respiratory diseases, given 302 the role of iNOS expression in immune response to respiratory 303 infection (Roodgar et al., 2013). Moreover, STAT-1 plays a key role 304 in inducing the expression of IFN-inducible 10kD protein (IP-10) 305 and interferon regulatory factor 1 (IRF-1), which are also known 306 to play key roles in innate immune response by macrophages Ohmori and Hamilton, 2001). Future in vivo investigations may 308 clarify the influence of genetic changes in STAT-1 binding sites in 309 iNOS regulatory regions across non-human primates on susceptispecies of NHP, African green monkeys, but not 313 members of the other species, exhibit a binding site for kruppel-314 like factor 6 (KLF6), a key transcription factor of iNOS. Several stud-315 ies indicate that KLF6, which transactivates iNOS expression Warke et al., 2003), plays a key role in immunity against viral 317 and bacterial respiratory infections. A direct interaction between 318 KLF6 and iNOS has been observed in in vitro infection of human 319 lung cells with influenza A virus (Mgbemena et al., 2012). KLF6 also 320 regulates apoptosis through the activation of iNOS expression and 321 plays a critical role in iNOS expression during respiratory syncytial 322 virus (RSV) (Mgbemena et al., 2013) and influenza A virus infection 323 (Mgbemena et al., 2012).324 3.4. FIGREF20.text: second candidate regulatory region for iNOS that we label R2 371 was mapped using the UCSC genome browser. The R2 region lays 372 approximately 700-1000 bp upstream of the first exon of iNOS 373 and was identified as a regulatory region candidate through visual 374 inspection of the UCSC genome browser (see Fig. 1) and literature 375 review (see Pautz et al., 2010). This region corresponds to the peak 376 of H3K4me3 in normal lung fibroblasts, and according to the UCSC 377 genome browser, contains several transcription factor binding sites 378 (TFBS). The location of the orthologous sequence in NHP species 379 was located using the UCSC genome browser and the Basic Local 380 Alignment Tool (BLAT).381 4.2.1. FIGREF22.text: region, R1 and R2, we investigated how variation in 468 RE/TF binding sites was associated with the classification of 469 animals into the K ¼ 3 major clusters observed in our data: African 470 green monkeys, Chinese and Indian rhesus macaques, and cyno-471 molgus and pig-tailed macaques. We used a categorical regression 472 model to predict the classification, Y ½n 2 f1 . . . Kg, of animal n using 473 data on the RE/TF binding profile of that animal. Each RE/TF bind-474 ing profile, X ½1...ðPþ1Þ;n , is a vector beginning with an intercept value 475 of 1, and continuing with P ¼ 105 (in R1, or P ¼ 95 in R2) binary 476 data points that indicate the presence or absence of the p th RE/TF 477 binding site in animal n. Because we had many more predictors 478 than animals in our sample, we used a full Bayesian regression 479 model with Laplace (also known as double exponential) priors on 480 the regression coefficients. This model formulation imposes the 481 Bayesian corollary of Lasso, or ' 1 -regularized regression, which 482 penalizes the number of non-zero parameter values, reducing 483
